channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Union president reacts to federal judge order to halt federal worker layoffs
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Lee Saunders — president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees — about how federal workers are handling the latest round of layoffs.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Lee Saunders — president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees — about how federal workers are handling the latest round of layoffs.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: The stakes of genocide: What it means and why it matters in Gaza
item.description: What are the stakes of calling an armed conflict a genocide? Even as a ceasefire agreement takes hold – the term continues to come up in relation to the war in Gaza.
item.content:encoded: What are the stakes of calling an armed conflict a genocide? Even as a ceasefire agreement takes hold – the term continues to come up in relation to the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Leah Donnella

item.title: Volunteers take over Oklahoma City National Memorial tours during government shutdown
item.description: Volunteers with ties to the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing have stepped up to give tours at the National Memorial there as park rangers are furloughed during the government shutdown.
item.content:encoded: Volunteers with ties to the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing have stepped up to give tours at the National Memorial there as park rangers are furloughed during the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Abigail Siatkowski

item.title: A murder in Minnesota's Iron Range launches Chris Kraus' newest novel
item.description: NPR's Elissa Nadworny speaks with Chris Kraus about her new novel, The Four Spent the Day Together.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Elissa Nadworny speaks with Chris Kraus about her new novel, The Four Spent the Day Together.
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: Earthworm magnetic navigation Earthworms may offer clues into magnetic navigation
item.description: Scientists have known for decades that many animals use the Earth's magnetic field for navigation. It's less clear how they do it. A new study suggests earthworms may be a good way to figure it out.
item.content:encoded: Scientists have known for decades that many animals use the Earth's magnetic field for navigation. It's less clear how they do it. A new study suggests earthworms may be a good way to figure it out.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: Supreme Court seems poised to further undercut the Voting Rights Act
item.description: The court's conservative majority could invalidate the section of the Voting Rights Act aimed at ensuring minority voters are not shut out of the process of drawing new congressional district lines.
item.content:encoded:
The court's conservative majority could invalidate the section of the Voting Rights Act aimed at ensuring minority voters are not shut out of the process of drawing new congressional district lines.

(Image credit: Claire Harbage)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: The LA Dodgers are 2 wins away from the World Series thanks to their starting pitchers
item.description: The starting pitching staff of the Los Angeles Dodgers has been on a tear this postseason -- allowing few hits and being truly dominant. Which is good, because the L.A. bullpen has struggled.
item.content:encoded: The starting pitching staff of the Los Angeles Dodgers has been on a tear this postseason -- allowing few hits and being truly dominant. Which is good, because the L.A. bullpen has struggled.
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: What's next for Gaza
item.description: Gaza's future is filled with hard questions. Consider these three: Who will govern the territory? Who will provide security? And who will be in charge of the money and reconstruction?
item.content:encoded: Gaza's future is filled with hard questions. Consider these three: Who will govern the territory? Who will provide security? And who will be in charge of the money and reconstruction?
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Don't panic, but there might be lead in your protein powder
item.description: NPR's Elissa Nadworny talks with investigative reporter Paris Martineau about a new Consumer Reports analysis that shows protein powders can contain toxic heavy metals, especially lead.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Elissa Nadworny talks with investigative reporter Paris Martineau about a new Consumer Reports analysis that shows protein powders can contain toxic heavy metals, especially lead.
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: The fighting has stopped, but dire need remains in Gaza
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks to David Miliband, the president and CEO of the International Rescue Committee, about the needs of Palestinians in Gaza moving forward.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks to David Miliband, the president and CEO of the International Rescue Committee, about the needs of Palestinians in Gaza moving forward.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly
